title: 2 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 21.

questions.question: How long did the famine last during the days of David according to 2 Samuel 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Three years
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:1 states that there was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year.

questions.question: Who did David inquire of about the cause of the famine?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:1 says that David enquired of the LORD, and the LORD answered him about the famine.

questions.question: Why did the LORD say the famine was happening?
options: Because of Saul and his bloody house
questions.correctAnswer: Because of Saul and his bloody house
questions.explanation: The LORD answered that the famine was for Saul and his bloody house because he slew the Gibeonites (2 Samuel 21:1).

questions.question: Who were the Gibeonites described as in relation to Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Remnant of the Amorites
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:2 explains that the Gibeonites were not of the children of Israel but were of the remnant of the Amorites.

questions.question: What did the Gibeonites refuse to accept from Saul's house?
questions.correctAnswer: Both Silver and Gold
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:4 states the Gibeonites said they would have no silver nor gold of Saul, nor of his house.

questions.question: How many men of Saul's sons did the Gibeonites ask to be delivered to them?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:6 says the Gibeonites requested seven men of Saul's sons to be delivered to them.

questions.question: Who did David spare among Saul's descendants?
questions.correctAnswer: Mephibosheth son of Jonathan
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:7 states that David spared Mephibosheth because of the LORD's oath between David and Jonathan.

questions.question: What did Rizpah do to protect the bodies of the executed men?
options: Spread sackcloth on a rock and guarded them
questions.correctAnswer: Spread sackcloth on a rock and guarded them
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:10 says Rizpah spread sackcloth on the rock and guarded the bodies from birds and beasts.

questions.question: Who helped David retrieve the bones of Saul and Jonathan?
questions.correctAnswer: The men of Jabeshgilead
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:12 reports David took the bones from the men of Jabeshgilead who had stolen them from the Philistines.

questions.question: Where were the bones of Saul and Jonathan buried?
options: In Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish
questions.correctAnswer: In Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:14 states that the bones were buried in the country of Benjamin in Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish his father.

questions.question: True or False: Ishbibenob was a giant who tried to kill David with a spear weighing three hundred shekels of brass.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:16 describes Ishbibenob as one of the sons of the giant, wielding a spear of three hundred shekels of brass, trying to kill David.

questions.question: Who saved David from Ishbibenob's attack?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:17 reveals that Abishai, son of Zeruiah, helped David by killing the Philistine Ishbibenob.

questions.question: True or False: Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Saph, one of the sons of the giant.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:18 says Sibbechai slew Saph, who was one of the sons of the giant.

questions.question: Who killed the brother of Goliath, according to 2 Samuel 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Elhanan
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:19 states Elhanan the Bethlehemite slew the brother of Goliath the Gittite.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The man of great stature in Gath had _____ fingers on each hand and _____ toes on each foot.
questions.correctAnswer: Six; six
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:20 describes a man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan son of Shimea killed the man of great stature who defied Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:21 confirms Jonathan, son of Shimea, killed the giant who defied Israel.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 21 teach us about the importance of seeking God's guidance in difficult times?
options: David inquired of the LORD during a famine
David ignored the famine and acted on his own
David consulted his advisors but not God
David blamed others for the famine
questions.correctAnswer: David inquired of the LORD during a famine
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:1 shows David seeking the LORD's guidance during a famine, teaching us to trust God and seek His wisdom in trials. This is supported by verses 1, 3, and 11 where David acts according to God's direction.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with forgiveness toward those who have wronged their family. Based on 2 Samuel 21, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s justice requires accountability, but mercy should temper actions
One should seek revenge for family wrongs immediately
Ignore wrongs and do not seek justice
Family loyalty means protecting all relatives regardless of sin
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice requires accountability, but mercy should temper actions
questions.explanation: David’s dealings with the Gibeonites (verses 2-14) show that justice for past wrongs is necessary but tempered with mercy, as seen in sparing Mephibosheth (verse 7). This teaches balancing justice with mercy.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and intercession can be learned from Rizpah’s actions in 2 Samuel 21?
options: Persevering in prayer and mourning can lead to God’s intervention
Mourning should be private and hidden
One should accept suffering without protest
Rely only on self for help in trials
questions.correctAnswer: Persevering in prayer and mourning can lead to God’s intervention
questions.explanation: Rizpah’s vigil (verses 10-11) demonstrates faithful, persistent mourning and intercession, which moved David to act and led to God being entreated for the land (verse 14), emphasizing perseverance in prayer.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 21 encourage us to uphold integrity and honesty in leadership?
options: David openly addressed the famine’s cause and acted justly
David hid the cause of the famine from the people
David ignored the problem hoping it would resolve itself
David blamed others to avoid responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: David openly addressed the famine’s cause and acted justly
questions.explanation: David’s transparency in seeking God’s will and taking responsibility for Saul’s wrong (verses 1-6) teaches leaders to be honest, upright, and accountable.

questions.question: What does the sparing of Mephibosheth teach us about faithfulness to promises and covenant relationships?
options: David honored his oath to Jonathan by sparing Mephibosheth
David ignored past promises to act quickly
David spared all sons of Saul without distinction
David spared Mephibosheth due to fear
questions.correctAnswer: David honored his oath to Jonathan by sparing Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: Verse 7 shows David’s faithfulness to his covenant with Jonathan, teaching the importance of honoring commitments and loyalty in relationships.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by ongoing spiritual battles and temptations. Based on David’s experiences in 2 Samuel 21, what encouragement can you offer?
options: Persevere in spiritual battles with God’s help, even when weary
Give up when feeling faint and overwhelmed
Avoid battle by hiding from challenges
Rely only on personal strength without God
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere in spiritual battles with God’s help, even when weary
questions.explanation: David’s faintness in battle (verse 15) but continued fight teaches perseverance in trials with God’s support, encouraging believers not to give up.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 21, God’s people must sometimes face consequences for the sins of their leaders and ancestors.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The famine in David’s time was due to Saul’s sin against the Gibeonites (verse 1), illustrating that consequences can impact people beyond the sinner, emphasizing the need for repentance and intercession.

questions.question: How does the story of the battles with giants in 2 Samuel 21 teach us about courage and reliance on God in facing formidable challenges?
options: David and his men trusted God and overcame giants
They relied on their own strength alone
They avoided fighting giants out of fear
They used deceit to defeat the giants
questions.correctAnswer: David and his men trusted God and overcame giants
questions.explanation: Verses 16-22 recount how David and his servants defeated giants, illustrating courage and reliance on God’s power to overcome obstacles.

questions.question: In 2 Samuel 21, what does the burial of Saul and Jonathan teach about honoring family and the importance of closure?
options: David ensured proper burial to honor family and bring peace
David left the bones unburied as punishment
David buried only Saul, ignoring Jonathan
questions.correctAnswer: David ensured proper burial to honor family and bring peace
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 describe David’s actions to recover and bury Saul and Jonathan’s bones, demonstrating respect for family and the importance of closure for healing.

questions.question: True or False: Rizpah’s protective vigil over the bodies of her sons shows a model of steadfast love and faithfulness even in suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 describe Rizpah’s faithful watch over her sons, exemplifying steadfast love and dedication despite hardship, encouraging believers to remain faithful in trials.

questions.question: How does the response of David’s men to his faintness in battle illustrate the biblical virtue of protecting and valuing leaders and fellow believers?
options: They swore David should not risk himself further in battle
They told David to fight harder regardless of risk
They allowed David to be alone in battle
questions.correctAnswer: They swore David should not risk himself further in battle
questions.explanation: Verse 17 shows David’s men protecting him, valuing his life as the light of Israel, teaching care and respect for leaders within the community.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by past family sins affecting their present life. Based on 2 Samuel 21, what biblical principle can be shared for restoration?
options: Repentance, intercession, and acting justly can bring restoration
The past is permanent and cannot be changed
Ignore the past and hope for the best
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance, intercession, and acting justly can bring restoration
questions.explanation: David’s actions (verses 1-14) in addressing Saul’s sin, interceding with the Gibeonites, and proper burial brought God’s favor back, teaching restoration through repentance and justice.

questions.question: How does the demand of the Gibeonites for Saul’s descendants illustrate the seriousness of sin and its consequences?
options: The Gibeonites required seven sons of Saul to be handed over for justice
They accepted silver and gold as payment
They demanded David’s own sons instead
questions.correctAnswer: The Gibeonites required seven sons of Saul to be handed over for justice
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 show the Gibeonites asking for Saul’s descendants for justice, illustrating that sin has serious consequences that must be addressed.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance in service does the story of Jonathan son of Shimea slaying the six-fingered giant teach us?
options: Faithful service in God’s work requires courage and persistence
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful service in God’s work requires courage and persistence
questions.explanation: Verse 21 highlights Jonathan’s courageous act, teaching believers to serve God faithfully with courage and determination regardless of position.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David’s inquiry to the LORD about the famine revealed it was due to Saul’s ________ house, because he slew the Gibeonites.
questions.correctAnswer: bloody
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 21:1 states the famine was because of Saul and his bloody house, referring to the bloodguilt from slaying the Gibeonites, emphasizing accountability.

questions.question: How does David’s gathering and burying of the bones in 2 Samuel 21 illustrate biblical stewardship over family legacy and memory?
options: He honored his ancestors by giving them proper burial
He refused to honor past generations
He destroyed the bones to erase the past
questions.correctAnswer: He honored his ancestors by giving them proper burial
questions.explanation: Verses 12-14 show David’s care to properly bury Saul and Jonathan, teaching respect and stewardship over family heritage and memory.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 21.

questions.question: What was the cause of the three-year famine during David's reign according to 2 Samuel 21?
options: Saul's bloody house due to slaying the Gibeonites
A drought in the land of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Saul's bloody house due to slaying the Gibeonites
questions.explanation: The famine lasted three years and was caused because Saul had slain the Gibeonites, as the LORD declared (2 Samuel 21:1).

questions.question: Who were the Gibeonites described as in 2 Samuel 21?
options: Remnant of the Amorites not of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Remnant of the Amorites not of Israel
questions.explanation: The Gibeonites were not Israelites but a remnant of the Amorites, and Israel had sworn to them (2 Samuel 21:2).

questions.question: What did the Gibeonites request from King David as restitution for Saul's actions?
options: Seven of Saul's sons to be hanged
A large sum of silver and gold
questions.correctAnswer: Seven of Saul's sons to be hanged
questions.explanation: The Gibeonites demanded seven of Saul's sons to be delivered to them to hang in Gibeah as justice (2 Samuel 21:6).

questions.question: Which son of Jonathan was spared by David because of an oath?
questions.correctAnswer: Mephibosheth
questions.explanation: David spared Mephibosheth, Jonathan's son, due to the oath between David and Jonathan (2 Samuel 21:7).

questions.question: How did Rizpah, the concubine of Saul, express her mourning over the deaths of her sons?
options: She spread sackcloth on a rock and guarded the bodies from birds and beasts
She fasted for seven days in the temple
She built a memorial for them in Gibeah
She anointed their graves with oil
questions.correctAnswer: She spread sackcloth on a rock and guarded the bodies from birds and beasts
questions.explanation: Rizpah spread sackcloth on a rock and kept vigil to protect the bodies from scavengers until rain came (2 Samuel 21:10).

questions.question: What action did David take after hearing about Rizpah's vigil?
options: He retrieved Saul and Jonathan's bones and buried them properly
He declared war on the Gibeonites
He offered sacrifices to the LORD
He built a monument to Rizpah
questions.correctAnswer: He retrieved Saul and Jonathan's bones and buried them properly
questions.explanation: David collected the bones of Saul and Jonathan from Jabeshgilead and buried them in Benjamin as commanded (2 Samuel 21:12-14).

questions.question: What is the significance of the burial of Saul and Jonathan in the sepulchre of Kish?
options: It fulfilled a royal burial custom and ended the famine
It marked the end of the Philistine wars
It established David as king over all Israel
It was a new covenant ritual
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfilled a royal burial custom and ended the famine
questions.explanation: The burial in Kish’s sepulchre fulfilled royal duties and led to God being intreated for the land, ending the famine (2 Samuel 21:14).

questions.question: Who was Ishbibenob, and what was notable about his weapon?
options: A giant whose spear weighed 300 shekels of brass
A Philistine king with a golden sword
David's chief captain with a famous bow
A Gibeonite warrior with a silver axe
questions.correctAnswer: A giant whose spear weighed 300 shekels of brass
questions.explanation: Ishbibenob was one of the giants whose spear was very heavy, weighing 300 shekels of brass (2 Samuel 21:16).

questions.question: Who saved David from Ishbibenob's attack, and what was the consequence?
options: Abishai killed Ishbibenob, and David was told not to fight anymore
Jonathan slew Ishbibenob, and David promoted him
Michal protected David, and peace was made
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai killed Ishbibenob, and David was told not to fight anymore
questions.explanation: Abishai rescued David by killing Ishbibenob, and afterward, David's men swore he would no longer go to battle (2 Samuel 21:17).

questions.question: Which city was the site of multiple battles against the Philistines involving the sons of giants?
questions.correctAnswer: Gob
questions.explanation: Battles at Gob included encounters where Sibbechai and Elhanan killed sons of giants (2 Samuel 21:18-19).

questions.question: Who slew the brother of Goliath the Gittite, and what was distinctive about his spear?
options: Elhanan; his spear's staff was like a weaver's beam
Jonathan; his spear was made of iron
Abishai; he used a sword instead of a spear
Sibbechai; his spear was twice the normal length
questions.correctAnswer: Elhanan; his spear's staff was like a weaver's beam
questions.explanation: Elhanan killed Goliath’s brother, who had a spear staff as large as a weaver’s beam (2 Samuel 21:19).

questions.question: Describe the giant from Gath mentioned in 2 Samuel 21 who had an unusual physical trait.
options: He had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot
He was twice as tall as Goliath
He had a lion's mane of hair
He had one eye like a cyclops
questions.correctAnswer: He had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot
questions.explanation: This giant had 24 digits in total, six fingers and six toes on each limb (2 Samuel 21:20).

questions.question: Who killed the giant with six fingers and toes, and what was his relation to David?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan, David's brother
questions.explanation: Jonathan, son of Shimea and David’s brother, killed the giant with six fingers and toes (2 Samuel 21:21).

questions.question: How many giants born in Gath were killed by David and his servants according to 2 Samuel 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Four
questions.explanation: Four giants born in Gath were slain by David and his servants (2 Samuel 21:22).

questions.question: True or False: David personally killed the giant Ishbibenob during the battle.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Abishai, not David, killed Ishbibenob to save David’s life (2 Samuel 21:16-17).

questions.question: True or False: The famine ended only after the bones of Saul and Jonathan were buried properly.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: After the bones were buried in Benjamin, God was intreated for the land and the famine ended (2 Samuel 21:14).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the reason given by the LORD for the famine during David's reign?
options: Because of Saul and his bloody house for slaying the Gibeonites
Because of David's sins against Israel
Because the Philistines were attacking Israel
Because the land was cursed for idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: Because of Saul and his bloody house for slaying the Gibeonites
questions.explanation: The famine was due to the bloodguilt of Saul's house because he slew the Gibeonites, as God revealed to David (2 Samuel 21:1). This reflects God's justice and the consequences of covenant violation (Numbers 35:33, Joshua 9:14, 2 Samuel 21:1, Ezekiel 18:20, Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: Who were the Gibeonites according to 2 Samuel 21?
options: Remnant of the Amorites, not Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: Remnant of the Amorites, not Israelites
questions.explanation: The Gibeonites were a remnant of the Amorites and not Israelites, but Israel had sworn to spare them (2 Samuel 21:2). This shows God's commitment to His covenant promises even with non-Israelites (Joshua 9:15, Romans 9:25, Matthew 5:37, Hebrews 6:13-17, Genesis 12:3).

questions.question: What did the Gibeonites refuse as compensation for Saul's wrongdoing?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver and gold
questions.explanation: The Gibeonites rejected silver and gold from Saul's house as compensation and instead requested the death of certain descendants to make atonement (2 Samuel 21:4). This highlights the seriousness of blood guilt and the need for just reparation, consistent with Old Testament law (Exodus 21:23-25, Leviticus 17:11, Numbers 35:30, Jeremiah 31:29, Hebrews 9:22).

questions.question: How many descendants of Saul did the Gibeonites demand to be handed over for execution?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven
questions.explanation: The Gibeonites asked for seven men of Saul's sons to be handed over to be hanged as a form of atonement (2 Samuel 21:6). The number seven often symbolizes completeness in biblical justice (Genesis 4:15, Leviticus 4:6, Numbers 29:12, Revelation 1:20, Hebrews 11:4).

questions.question: Why did King David spare Mephibosheth, son of Jonathan?
options: Because of the LORD's oath between David and Jonathan
Because he was not a descendant of Saul
Because the Gibeonites did not request him
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the LORD's oath between David and Jonathan
questions.explanation: David spared Mephibosheth due to the covenant oath he made with Jonathan, showing the importance of faithfulness to God's promises and covenant loyalty (2 Samuel 21:7). This reflects the biblical principle of covenant faithfulness (1 Samuel 20:8, Psalm 89:34, Romans 1:12, Hebrews 6:13-18, Matthew 5:37).

questions.question: What was Rizpah's response to the execution of Saul's descendants?
options: She guarded their bodies from scavengers until the rains came
She cursed the king for his actions
She fled to another city in mourning
questions.correctAnswer: She guarded their bodies from scavengers until the rains came
questions.explanation: Rizpah spread sackcloth on a rock and protected the bodies of the executed sons from birds and beasts until rain fell, demonstrating profound grief and respect for the dead (2 Samuel 21:10). This act reflects the ancient Near Eastern concept of honoring the dead and the biblical emphasis on mourning (Genesis 37:35, 2 Samuel 3:35, Ezekiel 37:1-14, Luke 7:13, Romans 12:15).

questions.question: What did David do after hearing of Rizpah's actions?
options: He retrieved the bones of Saul, Jonathan, and those executed for proper burial
He ignored the situation and continued ruling
He waged war against the Gibeonites
He offered sacrifices to appease God
questions.correctAnswer: He retrieved the bones of Saul, Jonathan, and those executed for proper burial
questions.explanation: David honored the dead by retrieving and properly burying the bones of Saul, Jonathan, and the executed sons, an act that brought God's favor upon the land (2 Samuel 21:11-14). Proper burial is a biblical duty showing respect for the body and God's design for death and resurrection (Genesis 50:25, 1 Kings 2:6, John 11:44, 1 Corinthians 15:42, Revelation 20:13).

questions.question: What was the outcome for the land after David performed the burial rites?
options: God was entreated for the land and the famine ceased
The famine continued for another year
The enemies of Israel increased their attacks
The people of Israel rebelled against David
questions.correctAnswer: God was entreated for the land and the famine ceased
questions.explanation: After David fulfilled the burial rites, God was entreated for the land, implying the famine ended, showing God's mercy upon repentance and obedience (2 Samuel 21:14). This illustrates God's covenantal responsiveness (2 Chronicles 7:14, Joel 2:13, Jonah 3:10, Psalm 85:6, James 4:8).

questions.question: Who helped David when Ishbibenob, a giant Philistine, tried to kill him?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai, son of Zeruiah
questions.explanation: Abishai rescued David by striking down the giant Ishbibenob, emphasizing the protection God provides through faithful servants (2 Samuel 21:16-17). This reflects God's providence and protection of His anointed (Psalm 91:11, 2 Samuel 22:3, Isaiah 41:10, Romans 8:31, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: What was the warning given to David after Abishai saved him from the giant?
options: David was told not to go out with them to battle anymore
David was promoted to lead the army
David was told to fight the giant himself next time
David was advised to flee from the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: David was told not to go out with them to battle anymore
questions.explanation: David's men warned him not to expose himself to danger lest he quench the 'light of Israel,' highlighting the king's spiritual and national significance (2 Samuel 21:17). This illustrates the biblical principle of protecting leadership that represents God's covenant people (Exodus 17:12, Psalm 27:1, John 8:12, Revelation 21:23, Proverbs 29:2).

questions.question: Who slew Saph, one of the sons of the giant, in the battle at Gob?
questions.correctAnswer: Sibbechai the Hushathite
questions.explanation: Sibbechai the Hushathite killed Saph, a giant's son, at Gob, indicating that God's people, empowered by Him, can overcome formidable enemies (2 Samuel 21:18). This aligns with God's promise to give victory over giants (Joshua 1:6-9, 1 Samuel 17:50, Psalm 18:39, Ephesians 6:10-11, Romans 8:37).

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 21, who killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite?
questions.correctAnswer: Elhanan son of Jaareoregim
questions.explanation: Elhanan, a Bethlehemite, killed Goliath's brother, showing that multiple servants of God played roles in defeating the enemies of Israel (2 Samuel 21:19). This supports the biblical theme of God raising up various instruments for His purposes (Judges 7:20, 1 Samuel 17:50, Psalm 44:5, Hebrews 11:32, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What physical anomaly did the giant from Gath possess?
options: Six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot
questions.correctAnswer: Six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot
questions.explanation: The giant had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot (24 in total), a sign of his extraordinary stature and perhaps symbolic of opposition to God’s people (2 Samuel 21:20). This anomaly recalls the Nephilim theme and the biblical motif of giants opposing God’s kingdom (Genesis 6:4, Numbers 13:33, Deuteronomy 3:11, 1 Chronicles 20:6, Ephesians 6:12).

questions.question: Who killed the giant with six fingers and toes in Gath?
options: Jonathan son of Shimea, David's brother
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan son of Shimea, David's brother
questions.explanation: Jonathan, David’s brother, slew the giant with six fingers and toes, illustrating that the Lord used multiple family members to defend Israel (2 Samuel 21:21). This underscores the biblical theme of God empowering His people to triumph against evil (1 Samuel 14:6, Judges 6:12, Psalm 144:1, Romans 8:31, Revelation 12:11).

questions.question: How many giants of Gath were slain by David and his servants according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Four
questions.explanation: Four giants born to Gath were slain by David and his men, highlighting the divine victory over Israel’s enemies and the fulfillment of God’s promises to protect His people (2 Samuel 21:22). This corresponds with the biblical narrative of God’s power prevailing over the enemies of His covenant people (1 Samuel 17:50, 2 Chronicles 20:15, Isaiah 41:10, Romans 8:37, Revelation 19:11-21).

questions.question: Which theme does the episode with the Gibeonites in 2 Samuel 21 best illustrate?
options: God's justice and the seriousness of covenant faithfulness
The futility of seeking God's guidance
The power of military might in securing peace
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and the seriousness of covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The famine and restitution through the Gibeonites illustrate God's justice and covenant faithfulness, emphasizing that sin affecting the community requires atonement (2 Samuel 21:1-14). This aligns with biblical theology on sin, justice, and covenant (Exodus 34:6-7, Leviticus 26:40-42, Ezekiel 18:30-32, Romans 3:23-26, Hebrews 9:22).
